name: trumpet
definition: A soprano brass instrument consisting of a long metal tube looped once and ending in a flared bell, the modern type being equipped with three valves for producing variations in pitch.
description:
A trumpet is a musical instrument commonly used in orchestral and jazz ensembles. The trumpet group contains the instruments with the highest register in the brass family.

Trumpets are played by blowing air through almost-closed lips, producing a buzzing sound that starts a standing wave vibration in the air column inside the instrument.

The tone quality may be changed by inserting a mute into the bell: either a conical straight mute of fibre or various aluminum mutes.

Early trumpets did not provide means to change the length of tubing, whereas modern instruments generally have 3 or sometimes 4 valves in order to change their pitch.

Classical music is written for solo trumpet, and trumpets are included in orchestras.

Trumpets play an important part in Jazz music, and other various popular genres. Sometimes, they also play short parts to emphasize sections in rock songs.

facts.name: Metal trumpets from Egypt
facts.value: The metal trumpet dates from the second millennium BCE in Egypt, when it was a small ritual or military instrument sounding only one or two notes.

facts.name: Lenghts from 60 centimeters to 2 meters
facts.value: Ancient trumpets had straight tubes about 60 centimetres long, but the medieval buisine, a straight instrument retaining the trumpet’s traditional association with royalty and pomp, reached a length of almost 2 metres.

facts.name: First trumpets was made of wood
facts.value: Eventually people started making trumpet like instruments with wood, for example, the cornetto, and later, with brass.

facts.name: Different mouthpieces
facts.value: Mouthpieces vary; orchestral players usually prefer a wider and deeper mouthpiece than dance-band and jazz players, who favour a narrower and shallower mouthpiece to produce a sustained forte in the high register.

facts.name: Ancient trumpet is called shofar
facts.value: An early example of a brass instrument like a trumpet is called a shofar, which is still used in religious ceremonies.

facts.name: Distinction between trumpet and horn
facts.value: The technical distinction between trumpet and horn is that one-third of the tube length of a trumpet is conical and two-thirds is cylindrical, while the horn’s tube is the opposite.

facts.name: The valved trumpet dates from 1828
facts.value: The valved trumpet appeared in Germany in about 1828. Its acceptance was delayed in the United States and Great Britain because players preferred the cornet in orchestral trumpet parts.

facts.name: Trumpets with extra coil
facts.value: The tonality, or key, of the instrument could be changed by the use of a crook, an extra coil of tubing inserted next to the mouthpiece.

facts.name: Years ago trumpets were very important
facts.value: Many years ago trumpets were very important. They were long and without valves. This meant a player had to control the pitch of the sound with only his mouth, which was very difficult.
